column1: Will Taiwan publicly accuse the People's Republic of China of flying a military aircraft over the territory of and/or the territorial waters surrounding the main island of Taiwan without its permission before 1 September 2022?
column6: ['Foreign Policy', 'US Politics', 'Security and Conflict', 'Non-US Politics']
Correcting, I mixed up the yes/no %.
Accidental submission.
Maybe tomorrow...
One more day…
Seems unlikely at this point
I mean 0.5%
US choppers in China 12 mile zone today
China AF pushing the lines...
@tabhuth
Late to the party on this one, seems very unlikely in so few days.
Doesn't look like this will happen before end of time period
Only a few days left

China runs 'close' to the 'Wall' of Taiwan

The crowd's 30% seems a bit high. To be sure, anything could happen, but there is only about a week left. I wanted to recommend this Twitter account to everyone https://twitter.com/MoNDefense It's the ROC Ministry of Defense, and it posts the flight paths of every ADIZ intrusion. Nothing has come close to the main island itself, although the PLAAF aircraft are certainly crossing the Taiwan Strait median line from time to time.
Crowd forecast looks accurate if this was for September 2023 rather than next week
The conflict de-escalated since Nancy Pelosi's visit. Other members of congress had visited recently, and China position was the same.
All quiet on Taiwan's radar screens as far as I can tell.
The exercises have ended, so moving this back down. Now, if all these &#%* delegations could just hold off until September please?
If with Pelosi there was non-occurrence, then it's hard for me to believe China will "break the line" with the latest US delegation visit to Taiwan (after Pelosi's).
Attentional all,
if after the largest military drill in 25 years Beijing has not send aircrafts over Taiwan's territory, it is unlikely it will happen in the next month.
Not much time left and it mostly seems like the risk is significantly lower than it was last week.
Taiwan's current military preparedness and China's lack of a strategic rationale for a provocation of this type leads me to lower my forecast substantially.

"US to conduct 'freedom of navigation' transit in Taiwan StraitThe US will launch air and maritime transit operations in the next few weeks. The move comes in response to China's 'more provocative and destabilizing behavior.' "
Tensions escalate, but not enough to triggers.....
Since both countries diplomatic ties are at its lowest, plus China has conducted live action drills close to the strait of Taiwan in recent days.

With China saying its task is "completed" I think we are back to the odds of this being a random accident. I give 1% for it being an accident and 3% for Taiwan announcing that China encroached within 12 nmi earlier, but delaying the announcement.
"China military 'completes tasks' around Taiwan, plans regular patrols
I'm gonna knock off like 1% per day as long as there are continuous drills around Taiwan
China pushing back...
https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2022/08/07/china-taiwan-military-drills/
"On Monday Taiwan said Chinese aircraft and ships had not entered its territorial waters during the exercises so far."

Hasn't happened yet, it is now August 8 in Taiwan and the drills were supposedly going to end after Aug 7, but I don't see any final confirmation that the drills have ceased. I have 15% left for drills continuing into tomorrow, or that the airspace was breached and it just hasn't been announced yet. Will drop to 0% if the drills end with no breach

Scaling back down it hasn't happened so far and while the current drills are not yet over (and such a violation could be a final point for dramaturgic reasons). Going below my estimate from before Pelosi both due to time having passed and due to "if not in this situation when else"

Going down further, these maps provide useful context assuming they're accurate. It looks like most of the zones have just been destinations for missiles, aircraft have only barely crossed the median line before turning back, and drones and warships have skirted around the island but with plenty of buffer. https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2022/world/asia/taiwan-china-maps.html
Drill seems to be near the end without further grave accusations of airspace violations.
NOTE as of 05 August, plus
Given Pelosi's visit and the current "drills" going on, bumping up the forecast.
Not the most humble source, anyway
China has all the incentive to do this as a pay back for the Pelosi visit. With this accusation by Taiwan, and a warning by US, all parties will climb down from their impossible positions
Are ballistic missiles considered "military aircraft?"

Maybe another way to look at this is to ask, "Will Taiwan shoot down a Chinese aircraft before 1 September 2022?" Or, "Will a Chinese aircraft be intercepted by Taiwanese aircraft before 1 September 2022?" Because if a territorial violation does occur, it's likely some form of these hypotheticals may transpire. Further, if my neighbor threatens to trespass my home, how often will I accuse him of coming onto my property? In the aggregate, I guess I'm around 50/50 still.
Nancy...

https://www.nytimes.com/2022/08/03/world/asia/taiwan-china-military-exercises.html"The Chinese military called the exercises a prelude to a bigger show of force intended to punish the island for a visit by Ms. Pelosi that challenged Beijing’s claims to Taiwan. The drills, jostling ever closer to Taiwan and expected to run 72 hours, will also give Chinese forces valuable practice should they one day be ordered to encircle and attack the island."

Went up to 100 before going to bed just in case, but it seems like things haven't escalated too much. I think it's plausible that China will try to go a bit further than the median line (which is usually their stopping point), but I'm not sure they will go as far as territorial waters. (They could also just be shot down before reaching Taiwanese territorial waters.)

"Taiwan’s defence ministry confirms Chinese missiles fired near MatsuTaiwan’s defence ministry appears to have confirmed those reports of missiles fired near Matsu. In a statement a short time ago it said the PLA had launched a number of Dongfeng series missiles into the waters northeast and southwest of Taiwan’s main island."

https://www.usnews.com/news/world-report/articles/2022-08-03/china-signals-plan-to-launch-missiles-over-taiwan-in-a-dramatic-troubling-escalationDo missiles count as "military aircraft"?h/t @SE_Meyer on https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/taiwan-defence-ministry-says-chinese-drills-seriously-violated-islands-2022-08-03/
Altering forecast. Tensions have increased in the area due to Pelosi trip. China has several options to respond as does Taiwan. No indication of likely responses as of yet.
Going up a bit, but still think we have better than even odds that it stays below this level

"Taiwan's defence ministry said on Wednesday that Chinese military drills have violated United Nations rules, invaded Taiwan's territorial space and amount to a blockade of its air and sea, amid high tensions as U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi visits the island."
Planned drills put Chinese forces within the territorial waters. I assume they plan to fly planes there. Over compensating a bit due to my lower forecast earlier.

Upping based on recent developments. However, I'm in the same camp as @Ryan-Beck on not overcorrecting - seeing as there is less than a month to go, all in the lead up to the National Congress, the escalation that triggering this question to resolve positively would imply is massive. Moreover, the strategical value would be questionable - as per my previous rationales, I maintain that the best place for China to start in Taiwan baring a full invasion (still extremely unlikely) is outside of the area delineated in the question.
Clearly my 1% is too low with these exercises starting up, so I have to readjust. The first rule in becoming a better forecaster is to change your mind when the facts change.

Increasing because the zones aren't necessarily characterized as zones to avoid for safety like I thought they might be (thanks to discussion with @probahilliby and @MrLittleTexas), though I do still think there's more likely to be a wide safety margin in the zones and that China won't risk one of their craft being shot down or escalating by actually crossing into Taiwan's territory.

Going up for the next few weeks while the exercises in response to Pelosi's visit are underway. As others are pointing out, these exercises look to be close to (or in some cases partly in?) Taiwan's territorial waters.

@erikbays I could see odds increasing once Pelosi leaves. Backed with new motivation and minus the beefed security put in place for Pelosi, it makes it easier to do such an incursion. Give China a week to position vessels around Taiwan and begin their controversial "exercises" like planned.
Now why would this time be different than in the '90s? China has grown so much economically and its military power has grown since too. This time around is more concerning than then.

I just saw the Chinese Ambassador to the US on CNN reading a script as if he was reciting a prayer or chant and for a long moment refused to be interrupted by the interviewer. This tells me the Chinese have passion for it (generalizing).

Okay, it seems that the new exercise zones surrounding Taiwan are closer and tighter than the one in the '90s during a similar crisis. I've verified through a Twitter user that the new zones are within 12nm of Taiwan's coast, so there is real plausibility here. It's highly likely fighters will also be employed to these naval zones. I'm still not sure if this will turn into some form of blockade or potential invasion once Pelosi is gone. The one in the '90s didn't. I'm still unsure if Chinese vessels are already in the area. The exercise window is within sailing range from Taiwan. Not sure if Chinese military vessels are already near the exercise zones or if they are taking the time to sail there. If they are already there.
Here's another one @MrLittleTexas

Live-fire exercises are planned in waters surrounding Taiwan in retaliation to Pelosi visit. Visually estimating, one zone looks to be within about 12nm of Taiwan's coast. Therefore, I bump up the odds.

That said, if China's economy worsens before 1 September 2022, Xi could be in need of a distraction, namely turning the focus to Taiwan by egging them on flying military aircraft over Taiwan's territorial waters.

I still think longterm the PLA will be ordered to bring Taiwan back to the flock. But it may give them pause to not wait another couple of years.

I believe China will test the US during the Ukraine crisis by encroaching on Taiwan and assessing US resolve and capabilities. Testing US resolve means gauging presidential willingness to sacrifice US lives for Taiwan. Testing US capabilities means measuring the size of the force. Showing we are not willing go all out for Taiwan means China will gain confidence in its plans to eventually take over Taiwan.
This would mean war and China is not yet ready for that

Still sticking to my prediction that Taiwan will not publicly accuse China of wrongdoing. However, Taiwan is drawing parallels to what is happening between Russia and Ukraine right now. https://www.nytimes.com/2022/02/23/world/europe/taiwan-china-ukraine.html

China is likely to keep hostilities in check until after the 2022 Olympics. Ties between Russia and China are strengthening while tensions with the US are rising. China also feels the desire to expand its local geographic influence and may exert pressures on Taiwan near the end of the year.
Go with the flow.

This is an interesting question drawing a parallel with the GJO question 'Will Russia be accused of invading Ukraine'. Taiwan will not be interested in provoking China even if China does indeed fly over the 12 nautical miles. This may play into China's hands to wear out Taiwan's forces by making them repeatedly scramble to warn away the aircrafts and let China attack Taiwan at its weakest. Based on Taiwan wanting peace and to remain independent, I give 90% probability of Taiwan not accusing China of wrongdoing. https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/taiwan-reports-new-large-scale-chinese-air-force-incursion-2022-01-23/

The 12 nautical miles is much more provocative than the Air Defense Identification Zone some of which actually covers the territory of mainland China!! Xi calibrates his 'provocations' and this will not gain any geopolitical advantage given that under the political posturing Taiwanese tech companies have increased their market share supplying chips made by them in China since Trump and Co. did their thing. Highly unlikely given the pain to gain ratio.

While I don't believe China will attempt to invade Taiwan or otherwise engage in some military confrontation, I can imagine that if there is an active conflict in Ukraine, China may decide to push a bit further than it has previously under the cover of that conflict. It may do so on the basis that the US will be predominantly focused on Russia and that flying a military aircraft over Taiwanese territory will not activate an American tripwire and therefore, the risk of provoking a strong response by the US will be minimal.

Seems like things has changed since my inital prediction. But still think the chance of Taiwan publicly accusing China of flying over being low. Up to 8% from 2 based on https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1375196

Mainland China will surely maintain its pressure campaign on Taiwan using ADIZ incursions. In fact, they have already maintained this behavior recently. I do not think that the PRC will fly a plane directly over the territory as this would be uncharacteristic brinksman behavior, but just because China's pressure peaked in October of last year does not mean that they are done.

Little reported was how close Chinese aircrafts came to Taiwan's air space in some kind of response to Japanese naval movements. A Russian invasion of Ukraine could give China cover to violate Taiwan's airspace. China may not want to do anything that might impact the "success" of the Olympic Games, but with opportunities present themselves. . .

My view is that the news is noise to this question. Even if there is a 90% chance of invasion or military attack, the requirements are so narrow that in my view, this is a low-probability event. The chances of an aerial military invasion would be a higher probability, in my judgement. But for Taiwan to accuse China and be territorial about its waters is not probable relative to just accusing China of invading land.

The moment is right to test the West's, especially the United States, commitment to Taiwan. Additionally, Xi had made it very clear in recent addresses that he intends to demonstrate the superiority of the Chinese model of government compared to Western democracies. This demonstration could come in the form of attempts to destabilize Taiwan's democracy.

The odds are rather significant that Taiwan will shoot down a militairy plane if it reaches its territorial airspace.

Publicly accusing China of violating its territorial integrity would likely be undesirable for Taiwan as it will pressure the US to recognize its independence and incentivize China to further assert its own claims to the island.

Unless there is a subject of interest within these boundaries (12nmi criterion), then I think it's virtually as likely that if a military aircraft flies within this proximity of Taiwan, it would also get to land or fly over land whether 500ft above land or 50,000 feet above land. Whatever, the case, I think Taiwan would call out the land invasion of airspace rather than strictly be territorial about its waters.

China is on the move globally and they really want Taiwan back in the fold. Xi is an imperialist of the first degree. Flying a military aircraft over their territory, should be the least of the Taiwan's concern, as it relates to China.

Post COVID-19, China will be looking to assert themselves militarily and brinksmanship will certainly increase. China as a matter of law, and the survival of Xi Jinpeg need to either invade Taiwan or utterly submit them. China will assert breaches into airspace and waters to ramp up pressure before this.

So far China has not flown over territorial waters (https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20211201-china-s-taiwan-jet-incursions-at-second-highest-level-in-november) and that would seem like a huge escalation. China might not been keen to escalate in 2022 due to both the Olympics and the CCP Congress where Xi should secure another 5-year term. Though it remains a possibility due to instability in the region and US-Taiwan language/behavior that is alarming China.

China has stepped up its military and political pressure on Taiwan so it is likely so I would say 50% it will happen but possibly Taiwan will if so not publicly accuse the People's Republic of China so I dropped to 30%

Putting a low probability on the basis of the "12 km" criterion. In lieu of an all-out war, there wouldn't really be any reason for China to send their aircraft that close to Taiwan as merely crossing into the Taiwanese ADIZ will get the world media's attention. ADIZs are not enforced by international law, so it's much lower risk for China. The primary purposes of these operations are: 1.) Intimidation (sending a political message), 2.) Chinese pilots get more experience, 3.) Forcing the smaller Taiwanese air force to wear itself out more. None of these requires flying inside Taiwan's territorial boundaries, and doing so would jeopardize foreign trade agreements such as the Comprehensive Agreement on Investment with the EU (see other GJ question). Looking at maps of some previous incursions into the ADIZ, I found nothing that indicates the Chinese sent aircraft anywhere close to the 12-mile mark (see example Chinese incursion-https://supchina.com/2021/10/05/taiwan-adiz-incursions-explaining-chinas-surge-in-warplane-activity-in-the-taiwanese-air-defense-zone/).
maintaining current forecast
Doubting that the "12 nautical miles" criterion could even be verifiable.

@Ed321 China and their ally Russia will push the envelope with the United States and our allies almost to the edge of war.China is still a weak nation and like Russia over compensates with bluster.However.We must remember when Russia invaded the Ukraine and violated the treaty they signed in 1994 we and our NATO allies did nothing.Sanctions don’t work! We have been sanctioning Cuba since I was a kid and I am now 75 years old with zero success.

China has trespassed Taiwan's air defense identification zone (ADIZ) at least weekly in all of 2021 (https://www.statista.com/chart/24620/chinese-military-aircraft-entering-taiwans-adiz/). Now the ADIZ is something like the space around the mid-field on your side (in football terms). I see you there, but I do not really think it is dangerous you are there. Countries have these ADIZ as a way of controlling air traffic around their territory. Taiwan would denounce this with certainty before 09/01/22.
While there is increasing military pressure from China, it is unlikely the PRC will attempt to enter Taiwan's soverign air space.
maintaining current forecast

Much will depend upon the build-up of events in the Taiwan straits. • Fall 2022 US is busy with Mid Term Elections. • China announces a blockade of Taiwan straits • Chinese warships take positions to close Straits for all shipping • Chinese Navy does not cross the median line but takes a posture on the Chinese side of the median line to close Taiwan straits, just an example only this can be done by assuming a flower or Octagon formation where fast Cruisers, missile gunboats take up positions on the outside and center contains Chinese aircraft carriers, destroyers. This way Chinese fleet is protected by its own naval aviation and air assets on the mainland. • Finally Chinese subs do cross the median line and take up positions on the northern and southern sides and at least a couple punch through into open waters to take a position in international waters but near Japan, Guam, and the Philippine Sea. Additionally, Chinese air and naval assets in the south China sea go on full alert and start surprise exercises. The dilemma in the above scenario is how will Taiwan, US, and its allies respond. Since the start of the current crises US and allied countries moves have been reactionary than proactive. Consider this Midterm election fever is in full swing so US response will definitely be reactionary than proactive, but what will be the response, China has only announced a blockade of Taiwan straits, but its naval and air assets have stayed on its side of the median line and not violated Taiwan side of the median line or its airspace. Additionally Chinese start a convoy of civilian supply ships to Kinmen and Matsu islands so they don’t run out of food, energy, and medical supplies. Again China has created a provocative move but stayed on its side of the median line, below are options before Taiwan and US • Option 1 Taiwan challenges the blockade and tries to sail civilian supply ships to Kinmen and Matsu. China responded by seizing these civilian vessels as soon as they cross their side of the median line, if these supply ships are provided armed escort, then China tries to seize those ships as well but only once they cross the median line and, in this instance, China goes one step further and moves its naval assets engaged in blockade beyond the median line and closer to Taiwan and starts patrolling Taiwanese airspace but does not attack Taiwan outright • Option 2 US and allied nations try to arrange a freedom of navigation convoy to challenge the blockade, this will take too much time to organize and once again many nations refuse to take part as again the median line has not been crossed, China responds by closing entire south China sea off-limits to countries other than the ones located in South China seas and also seizing Paratas Islands. This will be difficult for China, but its intimidation tactics may work, and other countries may refuse to join the US lead convoy and refuse permission to traverse their own territorial waters. China ups the ante by moving beyond the median line and patrolling Taiwan airspace but not attacking Taiwan • Option 3 Taiwan sees writing on the wall, it concludes that the US is busy with elections and is fumbling in its response, so it first decides to execute option 1 and then once China responds Taiwan starts a limited armed response to try and break the blockade forcing the US to either come to its defense or forever be cast aside as declining power.

Xi Jinping is likely to use the Taiwan question to distract from other questions within China and will probably increase pressure towards Taiwan. It he goes so far as to fly over Taiwan's territorial waters, Taiwan is very likely to make this public as soon as possible in order to gain support from the international community.

Although China is increasing pressure on Taiwan by flying sorties into its Air Defense Identification Zone, the closets they got was within 124 miles of the island. (1) An article in Foreign Affairs mentions 3 defense zones around the island: a “surveillance zone” of 30 nautical miles, a “warning zone” of 24 nautical miles and a “destruction zone” of 12 nautical miles. (2) It would be worrying if China starts testing these zones but the change would also be a lot smaller in the short term. especially entering the 12 miles and triggering the destruction of an aircraft wouldn't seem logical at this point, also taking into account the demand for action from the Chinese people at such a point and the escalation into full scale war that could follow. China wants to keep pressure on Taiwan, which it is currently doing. Entering the 12 mile zone, in my opinion, would be more in line with an imminent invasion than with keeping up pressure or testing defenses.
